results.title: Animated motion. Pt. 4
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Norman McLaren and Grant Munro
results.brief_description: In this fourth film, Norman McLaren explains and illustrates composite motion, where two of the categories of motion occur simultaneously in one action, as are the motions of jointed or pivoted parts (as occur in animal and human movements). Also shown is a human gesture with increasing amounts of emotion; and finally, the phenomenon of “strobing” in animation is examined.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ONF | NFB, Norman McLaren and Grant Munro

results.title: Animated motion. Pt. 3
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Norman McLaren and Grant Munro
results.brief_description: Zero motion and irregular motion (the other two of the five categories of motion) are examined by Norman McLaren in this part of the series. Immobility (or “zero motion”) and its duration, when occurring within a context of motion, plays a vital role in animation. The student sees how irregular motion, though seldom found in nature, can be used freely by the animator.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ONF | NFB, Norman McLaren and Grant Munro

results.title: Animated motion. Pt. 2
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Norman McLaren and Grant Munro
results.brief_description: In this second film, Norman McLaren presents the first three of the five categories of motion: constant, accelerated, and decelerated. Various types of acceleration and deceleration are demonstrated, and examples are shown of how these types of motion may be applied in regard to gesture, gravity, and perspective.

results.title: Animated motion. Pt. 1
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Norman McLaren and Grant Munro
results.brief_description: The first part of this series by Norman McLaren deals only with tempo. It starts by showing the disc travelling in one move (1/24 of a second) from A to B, and progressively demonstrates slower and slower tempos.

results.title: Animated geometry: the angle at the circumference
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Animated Geometry”.
Related to the basic theorem concerning the angle at the circumference. Two cases are studied, that of the angle having a diameter at one side and that angel including the centre between its sides. Series is: Animated geometry.

results.title: Animated genesis (TEFC)
results.brief_description: An allegory of the creation of the world, of man’s enslavement by the machine, motivated by Greed, which is personified as an enormous and menacing spider. It is eventually overthrown by the intervention of Goodness, but not before atomic warfare has resulted. The Foldes made the film at home, drawing all 32,000 pictures, and showed the 16mm result to Sir Alexander Korda, who had it blown up to 35mm for theatrical release. No other credits available.

results.title: Animated cartoons: the toy that grew up
results.creator_credit: Les Films du Compas and Roger Leenhardt
results.brief_description: The Toy that Grew Up is a study of the antecedents of cinema, dealing mainly with the developments which took place between 1800 and 1900. The invention of a child’s toy, called a traumatrope, led Belgian physicist Joseph Plateau to study a characteristic of the human eye called persistence of vision. He established that the retina of the eye retains an impression of a luminous object a full third of a second after the actual light source has disappeared. Plateau used this scientific fact as the basis for his invention of a machine which seemed to animate static drawings. Emile Reynaud perfected Plateau’s machine, inventing a machine called the Praxinoscope, which enabled him to show animated cartoons, and later to give theatrical performances, his cartoon shows lasting as long as a quarter of an hour.

Emile Reynaud perfected Plateau’s machine, inventing a machine called the Praxinoscope, which enabled him to show animated cartoons, and later to give theatrical performances, his cartoon shows lasting as long as a quarter of an hour.

results.title: Animated Alphabet
results.brief_description: Specially conceived and created for children and designed by expert British animators and educationalists, “Animated Alphabet” is an unprecedented learning experience and A-Z has NEVER been such fun. Using the voices of children to name the words and engaging special sound effects to vitalise the images, these bright and brilliant moving animations energise the alphabet as letters literally leap into life. The unique combination of colour, sound and movement will encourage any child and stimulate all imagination’s.
